''Moku'ume'ume'' (Island of Attraction)
''Poka {{okina}}Ailana'' (Ford Island) | sobriquet = | etymology = | image name = File:Aerial view of Ford Island Pearl Harbor 2013.JPG | image size = 250px | image caption = Ford Island, located within Pearl Harbor, Oahu, Hawaii. | image alt = A color photo of Ford Island with modern and historical buildings surrounding a runway overrun with grass | locator map = File:NOAA Pearl Harbor Approach Map.jpg | locator map size = 240px | map caption = Nautical chart of [[Pearl Harbor]] showing Ford Island in the northeast section | location = [[Oahu]], [[Hawaii]] | coordinates = {{coord|21|21|50|N|157|57|37|W|type:isle|display=title, inline}} | archipelago = | waterbody = East, Loch, [[Pearl Harbor]] | total islands = | country = United States | major islands = | area acre = 441 | area footnotes = | rank = | length mi = 1.5 | length footnotes = | width mi = 0.75 | width footnotes = | coastline km = | coastline footnotes = | elevation m = | elevation footnotes = | population = 368 | population as of = 2000 | population footnotes = {{cite web|url=http://www.corporateservices.noaa.gov/~ocao/irc/ford-island.html|title=History of Ford Island|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} | population rank = | population rank max = | density km2 = | density rank = | density footnotes = | ethnic groups = | website = | additional info = }} '''Ford Island''' ({{lang-haw|Poka {{okina}}Ailana}}) is an [[islet]] in the center of [[Pearl Harbor]], [[Oahu]], in the U.S. state of [[Hawaii]]. It has been known as '''Rabbit Island''', '''Marín's Island''', and '''Little Goats Island''', and its native Hawaiian name is '''''Moku{{okina}}ume{{okina}}ume'''''. The island had an area of {{convert|334|acres}} when it was surveyed in 1825, which was increased during the 1930s to {{convert|441|acres}} with fill [[dredge]]d out of Pearl Harbor by the [[United States Navy]] to accommodate [[battleship]]s. It was the site of an ancient Hawaiian fertility ritual, which was stopped by [[Christian]] missionaries during the 1830s. The island was given by [[Kamehameha I]] to Spanish deserter [[Francisco de Paula Marín]], and later returned to the [[monarchy]]. After the island was bought at auction by James Isaac Dowsett and sold to Caroline Jackson, it became the property of Dr. [[Seth Porter Ford]] by marriage and was renamed Ford Island. After Ford's death, his son sold the island to the [[John Papa ʻĪʻī]] estate and it was converted into a [[sugarcane]] [[Sugar plantations in Hawaii|plantation]]. In 1916, part of Ford Island was sold to the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] for use by an aviation division in Hawaii, and by 1939 it was taken over by the U.S. Navy as a station for battleship and [[submarine]] maintenance. From the 1910s to the 1940s, the island continued to grow as a strategic center of operations for the U.S. Navy in the Pacific Ocean. Ford Island was at the center of the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] and on the U.S. Pacific Fleet by the Japanese fleet on December 7, 1941. It was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1964, and {{as of|2011|lc=y}} the [[National Trust for Historic Preservation]] has listed the island as one of the United States' most-endangered historic sites.{{cite web|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2001/Jul/07/ln/ln04a.html|title=Ford Island's aging historic sites face new assault|author=Will Hoover|newspaper=Honolulu Advertiser|date=July 7, 2001|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} By the late 1990s, hundreds of millions of dollars had been invested in real estate development and infrastructure, including a new bridge. Ford Island continues to serve an active role in the Pacific, hosting military functions at the Pacific Warfighting Center and civilian functions at [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]'s [[Pacific Tsunami Warning Center]]. The island has been featured in films such as ''[[Tora! Tora! Tora!]]'' and ''[[Pearl Harbor (film)|Pearl Harbor]]'' and receives tourists from the U.S. and abroad at the [[USS Arizona Memorial|USS ''Arizona'' memorial]] and the [[USS Missouri (BB-63)#Museum ship (1998 to present)|USS ''Missouri'' museum]]. ==Geography== Ford Island is located inside Pearl Harbor, South O{{okina}}ahu of the Hawaiian Islands.{{cite book|title=Merriam-Webster's Geographical Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Co_VIPIJerIC&pg=PA390|location=Massachusetts|year=1997|publisher=Merriam-Webster|isbn=978-0-87779-546-9|page=390}} Pearl Harbor is divided into three large bodies of water called the West Loch, Middle Loch and East Loch with Ford Island in the center of the East Loch. It is {{convert|1.5|mile}} long and {{convert|0.75|mile}} wide, and was enlarged from {{convert|334|to|441|acre}} between 1930 and 1940 with land fill dredged from the surrounding harbor.{{cite report|url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/rods/fulltext/r2011090004192.pdf | format=PDF |title=Record of Decision Ford Island Land fill|publisher=Department of the Navy|date=September 2011|accessdate=May 25, 2014}} The land is a relatively flat plain rising from {{convert|5|to|15|ft}} above mean water level, and slopes toward Pearl Harbor. It connects to the larger island of O{{okina}}ahu, surrounding Pearl Harbor, via a {{convert|4672|ft|m|abbr=yes|adj=on}} bridge at its northern tip which crosses east to Halawa Landing.{{cite journal|last=Cho|first=Aileen|title=A Buoyant Crossing|journal=Engineering News-Record|date=August 18, 1997|volume=239|issue=7|pages=34, 35, 37 |publisher=McGraw-Hill|issn=0013-807X |oclc=761166077}} The island's soil is composed primarily of [[volcano|volcanic]] material, [[lagoon]]al deposits and [[coral]]line debris, with silty sand from the dredging. Its volcanic material is [[Aeolian processes|Aeolian ash]], weathered [[tuff]] and [[basalt]]. Ford Island proper is a coral outcrop. There are two smaller islets near the island: Mokunui and Mokuiki.Cantor 2008, p. 58. ===Contamination=== In 1991, the Navy discovered nine metals, two semi-volatile [[organic compound]]s and a [[polychlorinated biphenyl]] in Ford Island's [[soil contamination|soil]], groundwater and marine sediment. Suspected sources were nine {{convert|225000|gal|adj=on}} fuel tanks on the east-central side of the island (from 1924 to 1954), a {{convert|4.4|acre|adj=on}} [[landfill]] on the southwestern shore (from 1930 to 1960) and ordnance bunkers on the northeastern side. An investigation suggested covering the contaminated areas with clean soil. In 1994, the Navy considered removing the contaminated soil and installed six wells to monitor groundwater, but decided to follow the original recommendation in 1995 and capped the contaminated soil with topsoil and erosion-resistant vegetation (including [[Bermuda grass]]). The containment system was completed in 1996. ==Flora and fauna== The wildlife on Ford Island is likely very similar to that on [[Naval Station Pearl Harbor]].{{cite book|title=Hawaii Range Complex: Environmental Impact Statement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=At43AQAAMAAJ|publisher=US Department of the Navy|location=Washington D.C.|volume=2|year=2008|pages=467–468}} Wildlife is sparse and dominated by [[invasive species]] such as the [[house mouse]], [[mongoose]], [[brown rat]], [[black rat]], [[house sparrow]], [[Java sparrow]] and [[common myna]]h. An endangered owl, the endemic [[pueo]] (a subspecies of the [[short-eared owl]]), has been seen hunting on the island. Nearly all the plant life on the island is non-native,{{cite book|title=Programmatic EIS, Ford Island Development, Pearl Harbor: Environmental Impact Statement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ndw3AQAAMAAJ|year=2002|page=3|location=Washington D.C.|publisher=US Department of the Navy}} including [[Cactus#Uses|edible cacti]] from [[California]] introduced in the late 1700s by Francisco de Paula Marín.Gast & Marín 1937, p. 37. The island's harbor was important to ancient Hawaiians for its ample supply of fish, including [[Mullet (fish)|mullet]], [[milkfish]] and Hawaiian [[anchovy]]. The [[National Park Service]] and the [[United States Fish and Wildlife Service]] oversee and administer the World War II Valor in the Pacific National Monument battlefields at Pearl Harbor and Ford Island.{{cite book|author=Erika Doss|title=Memorial Mania: Public Feeling in America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-RiQiBwzFCcC&pg=PA56|year=2012|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|isbn=978-0-226-15939-3|page=56}} ==History== {{see also|History of Hawaii}} ===Ancient Hawaiians=== [[Ancient Hawaiian]]s called the island ''Moku{{okina}}ume{{okina}}ume'' ("isle of attraction" or "island of strife"),Sterling & Summers 1978, pp. 57–58.Doughty 2010, p. 102.Dorrance 1998, p. 145. after the ceremony (''{{okina}}ume'') held during the [[Makahiki]] festival for married couples who were having difficulty conceiving children.{{cite news|url=http://www.15wing.af.mil/shared/media/document/AFD-061130-036.pdf | format=PDF |title=Moku Umeume and Kapuaikaula Makahiki "A Hawaiian Thanksgiving"|date=November 17, 2006|publisher=Hickam Kukini|page=B2|accessdate=June 5, 2014}} In the [[Hawaiian language]] the word ''moku'' means to cut or sever in two, as well as an island or inlet.{{cite book|author=Ko-mike Hua?o-lelo|title=M_maka Kaiao|url=http://ulukau.org/elib/cgi-bin/library?e=d-0mkd-000Sec--11haw-50-20-frameset-book--1-010escapewin&a=d&d=D0.3.9&toc=0|date=January 2003|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Hawaii|pages=122–141|isbn=978-0-8248-2803-5}}{{cite book|author=Mary Kawena Pukui|title=Hawaiian Dictionary: Hawaiian-English, English-Hawaiian|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bHdRhjL9Y9EC&pg=PA252|date=January 1, 1986|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Hawaii|isbn=978-0-8248-0703-0|page=252}} The word ''{{okina}}ume'' means to draw, attract or entice{{cite book|author=Harvey Rexford Hitchcock|title=An English-Hawaiian Dictionary: With Various Useful Tables: Prepared for the Use of Hawaiian-English Schools|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D4Q0AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA24|location=California|year=1887|publisher=Bancroft Company|page=24}} and was used to name the ceremony for the common people.{{cite web |url=http://wehewehe.org/gsdl2.85/cgi-bin/hdict?e=q-11000-00---off-0hdict--00-1----0-10-0---0---0direct-10-ED--4-------0-1lpm--11-haw-Zz-1---Zz-1-home-ume--00-3-1-00-0--4----0-0-11-00-0utfZz-8-00&a=d&d=D20165|title=Hawaiian Dictionaries |author=Mary Ma-maka Kaiao Kuleana kope |year= |publisher=University of Hawaii Press |accessdate=June 24, 2014}} Hawaii historian [[Herb Kawainui Kāne]] considered ''{{okina}}ume'' to be a courtship game.Ka-ne 1997, p. 109. Those selected for ''{{okina}}ume'' (never virgins or the unmarried) would sing around a large bonfire while a tribal leader with a ''maile'' (wand) chanted, touching individual men and women. Those who were touched would find a secluded part of the island to have sex. Husbands and wives were not paired, and jealousy was discouraged. Children born of these unions were considered children of the husband, not the biological father. By 1830, this activity was forbidden by Christian missionaries.{{cite web|url=http://www2.hawaii.edu/~turner/oahu/fordisland.html|title=Ford Island|author=Dante Ignacio|publisher=University of Hawaii|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} The native Hawaiian people of the area were called ''Ke Awalau o Pu{{okina}}uloa''.{{cite web|title=I ka wa- ma mua, ka wa- ma hope: Exploring Pearl Harbor's present pasts |url=http://hawaiiindependent.net/story/i-ka-waa-ma-mua-ka-waa-ma-hope-exploring-pearl-harbors-present-pasts|author=Kyle Kajihiro|date=December 6, 2011|work=The Hawaii Independent|accessdate=May 22, 2014}} They used the island to cultivate watermelon and to harvest [[Heteropogon contortus|pili grass]] for the construction of [[thatching|thatched roofs]]. According to Hawaiian legend, the goddess [[Kaʻahupahau]] killed a girl on the island; remorseful, she then proclaimed a law forbidding further killing. Ka{{okina}}ahupa-hau's brother Kahi{{okina}}uka (sometimes referred to by historians as her son, Ku-maninini) was said to live in an underwater cavern off Ford Island{{cite report|title=AIS Report West Oahu Farrington Highway Section 3-Background Research|url=http://www.honolulutransit.org/media/50597/20111206-aisp-wofh-sec3.pdf | format=PDF |page=75|publisher=Honolulu Transit|date=November 6, 2011|accessdate=May 28, 2014}} with [[Kanekua?ana|Kanekua{{okina}}ana]], a giant water lizard which supplied food to the people of [[ʻEwa Beach, Hawaii|ʻEwa Beach]]. ===Kamehamehas and 18th-century settlers=== [[File:Moku'ume'ume.png|thumb|right|alt=Hand-drawn map of Ford Island and surrounding area|Map of Moku{{okina}}ume{{okina}}ume, compiled from maps dated 1873 to 1915]] Although no historical records provide an exact date, researchers at the [[Hawaiian Historical Society]] believe that the island was given to Francisco de Paula Marín on February 9, 1818, and later named after him for his assistance in providing weapons used by Kamehameha I to conquer the island of [[O'ahu|O{{okina}}ahu]]. However, Marín wrote in an 1809 journal entry that he was given the island and its adjacent fishing waters as early as 1791.{{cite web|url=http://hawaii.gov/hawaiiaviation/hawaii-airfields-airports/oahu-pre-world-war-ii/History%20of%20NAS%20128%20%28PH%29%201945.pdf | format=PDF |title=History of Naval Air Station, Navy Number 128|author=W. L. Peterson|publisher=U.S. Naval Air Station|date=January 15, 1945|accessdate=May 22, 2014}} He used the land to raise sheep, hogs, goats and rabbits as provisions for ships, and grew plants and vegetables which he had imported. In 1825, Admiral [[George Byron, 7th Baron Byron|George Byron, the 7th Baron Byron]] arrived, commanding the [[HMS Blonde (1819)|HMS ''Blonde'']], to return the remains of [[Kamehameha II]] and Queen [[Kamāmalu]] after their deaths in England of [[Measles]].{{cite book|author=James Macrae|title=With Lord Byron at the Sandwich Islands in 1825: Being Extracts from Thems. Diary of James Macrae ... |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6aYcAAAAMAAJ|year=1922|location=Michigan|publisher=W.F. Wilson|page=1}} While on Oahu, he would map the Pearl River (known today as [[Pearl Harbor]]). The ship's naturalist, Andrew Bloxam, spent time on Ford Island hunting rabbits and wild ducks; its surveyor, [[Lieutenant]] [[Charles Robert Malden]], called it ''Rabbits Island''. In 1826, [[Hiram Paulding]] became the first American naval officer to visit the island. Marín's ownership claim to the island was cloudy; Hawaiians generally refused to recognize land ownership by foreigners. Kamehameha II believed that the island had been loaned to Marín and by the 1850s the island was split between [[Kamehameha IV]]—who purchased {{convert|214|acre}}—and High Chiefess [[Kekauōnohi]], granddaughter of Kamehameha I, who was awarded {{convert|147|acre}} in the [[Great Māhele]].{{cite web|url=http://ulukau.org/cgi-bin/hpn?e=d-0mahele--00-0-0--010---4------0-0l--1en-Zz-1---20-about---000321-00110escapewin-00&a=d&c=mahele&cl=CL2.10&d=HASH018d288ef25ef6e9a781c921|title=Hawaii Place Names: Mokuumeume|publisher=ULUKAU: The Hawaiian Electronic Library|accessdate=June 6, 2014}} On August 28, 1865, the island was bought at public auction for $1,040 by James I. Dowsett, who sold it to Caroline Jackson for $1 on December 28. Dr. Seth Porter Ford arrived in 1851 from Boston, and practiced medicine at the U.S. Seamen's Hospital.Sterling & Summers 1978, p. 58.{{cite news |title= Ford Island has a checkered, colorful past |date= April 13, 1998 |author= Gregg K. Kakesako |newspaper= [[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]] |url= http://archives.starbulletin.com/98/04/13/news/story2.html |accessdate= March 8, 2011 }} Ford married Caroline Jackson in June 1866, taking control of the island and changing its name from Marín Island to Ford Island. When Ford died in 1866, it was transferred to his son, Seth Porter Ford, Jr.Dorrance 1998, p. 146.{{cite book |author=Eliakim Reed Ford |title=Ford genealogy: being an account of the Fords who were early settlers in New England. More particularly a record of the descendants of Martin-Mathew Ford of Bradford, Essex Co., Mass |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L0RMAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA21 |location=Wisconsin|year=1916 |publisher=The author|pages=20–21}} The island was managed by [[Sanford B. Dole]] on behalf of Ford's minor children until Ford, Jr. came of age and sold the island in 1891 to the John Papa ʻĪʻī land trust.{{cite news|title=Lease of the Island of Mokuumeume|author=S. B. Dole|newspaper=The Hawaiian Gazette|date=July 31, 1972|accessdate=October 14, 2014|subscription=yes|via=Newspapers.com|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/49685563/}}{{cite web|url=http://historichawaii.org/?wpdmact=process&did=ODM0LmhvdGxpbms=|title=Mokuʻumeʻume|author=William Dorrance|newspaper=Historic Hawaii Newsletter|date=December 1991|volume=17|issue=12|accessdate=February 13, 2014}} ===Sugar reciprocity=== [[File:Charles Reed Bishop and Bernice Pauahi Bishop in San Francisco, Kamehameha Schools Archives.jpg|175px|thumb|Charles Reed Bishop with his wife, Bernice Pauahi Bishop|alt=An old man in a top hat with a white beard stands next to a sitting woman in a decorative dress]] Sugar had been a major export from Hawaii since Captain [[James Cook|James Cook's]] arrival in 1778.Deerr 1949, p. 13. During the 1850s, the U.S. import tariff on sugar from Hawaii was much higher than the import tariffs Hawaiians were charging the U.S., and [[Kamehameha III]] sought reciprocity.Pratt 1939, pp. 260–261. As early as 1873, a United States military commission recommended attempting to obtain Ford Island in exchange for the tax-free importation of sugar to the U.S.{{cite web|title=Ford Island History|url=http://hawaii.gov/hawaiiaviation/hawaii-airfields-airports/oahu-pre-world-war-ii/ford-island|publisher=State of Hawaii|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} At that time [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] [[John Schofield]], U.S. commander of the military division of the Pacific, and [[Brevet (military)|Brevet]] [[Brigadier general (United States)|Brigadier General]] Burton S. Alexander arrived in Hawaii to ascertain its defensive capabilities. U.S. control of Hawaii was considered vital for the defense of the west coast of the United States, and they were especially interested in [[Iroquois Point, Hawaii|Pu'uloa]], Pearl Harbor.Dye 1997, p. 115. The sale of one of Hawaii's harbors was proposed by [[Charles Reed Bishop]], a foreigner who had married into the [[House of Kamehameha|Kamehameha family]], had risen in the government to be [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Hawaii)|Hawaiian Minister of Foreign Affairs]], and owned a country home near Pu'uloa. He showed the two U.S. officers around the lochs, although his wife, [[Bernice Pauahi Bishop]], privately disapproved of selling Hawaiian lands. As monarch, [[Lunalilo|William Charles Lunalilo]], was content to let Bishop run almost all business affairs but the ceding of lands would become unpopular with the native Hawaiians. Many islanders thought that all the islands, rather than just Pearl Harbor, might be lost and opposed any cession of land. By November 1873, Lunalilo canceled negotiations and returned to drinking, against his doctor's advice; his health declined swiftly, and he died on February 3, 1874. Lunalilo left no heirs. The legislature was empowered by the constitution to elect the monarch in these instances{{cite book|author=Daniel S. Murphree|title=Native America: A State-by-State Historical Encyclopedia [3 volumes]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0UNzFCOYTU4C&pg=PA268|date=March 9, 2012|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-38127-0|location=California|page=268}} and chose [[Kalākaua|David Kalākaua]] as the next monarch.MacLeod & Rehbock 1994, p. 494. The new ruler was pressured by the U.S. government to surrender Pearl Harbor to the Navy. Kalākaua was concerned that this would lead to annexation by the U.S. and to the contravening of the traditions of the Hawaiian people, who believed that the land ('Āina) was fertile, sacred, and not for sale to anyone. In 1875, the United States Congress agreed to an additional seven years of reciprocity in exchange for Ford Island. At the end of the seven-year reciprocity agreement, the United States showed little interest in renewal. [[File:Map of Ford's Island, Oahu, H. T. - NARA - 77-WDMC Hawaii-82.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Map of the island, with significant features enlarged|Map of O{{okina}}ahu Sugar Plantation on Ford Island, August 13, 1914|alt=A hand-drawn map depicting Ford Island with three sections drawn in a larger scale. Clear tape covers parts of the map.]] On January 20, 1887, the United States began leasing Pearl Harbor. Shortly afterwards, a group of mostly non-Hawaiians calling themselves the ''Hawaiian Patriotic League'' began the [[Hawaiian Rebellions (1887–95)|Rebellion of 1887]].{{cite book|author=Anne Lee|title=The Hawaii State Constitution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UvdoAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA7|location=New York|date=March 18, 2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-987796-6|page=7}} They drafted their own constitution on July 6, 1887.{{cite book|author=Jon M. Van Dyke|title=Who Owns the Crown Lands of Hawai_i?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IjZPcGb2R08C&pg=PA123|year=2008|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=Hawaii|isbn=978-0-8248-3211-7|page=123}} The new constitution was written by [[Lorrin Thurston]], the Hawaiian Minister of the Interior who used the Hawaiian militia as threat against Kalākaua.{{cite book|author=Mirza Ph.D, Rocky M.|title=American Invasions: Canada to Afghanistan, 1775 to 2010: Canada to Afghanistan, 1775 to 2010|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c4wHBI7mZGIC&pg=PA80|location=Indiana|date=September 2, 2010|publisher=Trafford Publishing|isbn=978-1-4669-5688-9|page=80}} Kalākaua was forced to dismiss his cabinet ministers and sign [[1887 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii|a new constitution]] which greatly lessened his power. It would become known as the "[[Bayonet Constitution]]" due to the force used. With support from California (because the state had profited from the import of sugar), Kalākaua again approached Congress.Curtis 1966, p. 218. When the United States still seemed uninterested in reciprocity, he threatened to forge more favorable export agreements with Australia or New Zealand. Congress feared that a treaty between Hawaii and Australia or New Zealand would result in annexation by one of those countries instead of the United States. Although Kalākaua was loath to give any foreign country land in Hawaii, he signed the treaty in September 1887. The Oahu Sugar Company (also known as the Oahu Sugar Cane Plantation) leased about {{convert|300|acre}} from the John Papa ʻĪʻī estate (after their purchase of the island in 1891) to harvest sugar in 1899. The business was successful, and the company sublet land from [[Benjamin Dillingham]] on the Waipi'o peninsula (southeast of present [[Waipio, Hawaii|Waipio]]) to build a 12-roller mill and railroad.Dorrance & Morgan 2000, p. 49. Sugarcane was grown and harvested on Ford Island with a network of [[aqueduct (water supply)|aqueducts]] from freshwater reservoirs, transported to Waipio by barge and then by rail to the mills. In 1902, the nearby estate of Bernice Pauahi Bishop lost a crucial lawsuit brought by the United States to purchase land around Pearl Harbor for below its market value.{{cite news|title=United States is successful in first of the lawsuits|newspaper=The San Francisco Call|date=December 26, 1901|volume=91|issue=26|url=http://cdnc.ucr.edu/cgi-bin/cdnc?a=d&d=SFC19011226.2.32#}} Although the Bishop estate valued the land at $600 per acre, the United States was only willing to pay $30 per acre. A jury determined that the land would be sold to the United States at $75 per acre. Facing a similar lawsuit and interest in its land on Ford Island, the John Papa ʻĪʻī estate settled with the United States to deed twenty-five acres at no cost. In exchange, the U.S. dropped its suit for the entire island. [[File:1918-12-16 Luke Field.jpg|thumb|250px|Earliest known aerial photo of Ford Island taken December 16, 1918|alt=A black and white photo from the air of the Luke Field portion of Ford Island in 1918.]] The military leased sections of the north and south sides of the island—{{convert|25.83|acre}} for $3,000—from the John Papa ʻĪʻī estate to build {{convert|6|in|cm|adj=on}} gun batteries: Battery Boyd and Battery Henry Adair.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=enlQAAAAYAAJ|title=Elihu Root collection of United States documents: Ser. A.-F.|page=131|publisher=Government Printing Office|location=Washington, D.C.|year=1902|author1=Elihu Root|author2=United States}} In 1917, the John Papa ʻĪʻī estate agreed to sell part of the Island to the United States for construction of an airfield, despite the Oahu Sugar Company complaining in court that the sale would hurt their business. ===Army Air Service=== [[File:1918-8-15 Martin GMB 01.jpg|thumb|250px|alt=Two biplanes on a runway: a twin-engine in the foreground and a single-engine in the background|[[Martin MB-1]] on Luke Field on August 15, 1918]] In 1917, the [[6th Aero Squadron]] was created in [[Honolulu]], with [[Captain (United States O-3)|Captain]] [[John F. Currey]] as its commander. Although 50 were assigned,Burlingame 2013, p. 29. only 49 arrived; one deserted en route. Currey chose Ford Island as the location for the new squadron and bought it from the John Papa ʻĪʻī land trust for $236,000, citing its access to water and winds as assets.Burlingame 2013, p. 31. When Currey was transferred to [[Washington (state)|Washington]], command of the squadron was given to Captain John B. Brooks and then Major [[Hugh J. Knerr]], who built hangars and a runway.{{cite news|url=http://hawaii.gov/hawaiiaviation/aviation-photos/1930-1939/luke-field/1939-11-4%20Lt.%20Frank%20Luke.jpg/ha_image_view_fullscreen|title=Luke Field passes on|author=Frank Hewlett|date=November 4, 1939|work=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|accessdate=May 16, 2014}} Early soldiers had to level the island, removing hills and boulders.Lee 1966, p. 303. All housing and major hangars were completed in 1918, including a large steel-and-wood hangar, two concrete hangars for seaplanes and flying boats, a supply warehouse, a machine shop, a photography laboratory and a powerhouse. In 1919, the field was named Luke Field after [[Frank Luke]], a World War I [[flying ace|ace]] and [[Medal of Honor]] recipient. The U.S. Army's introduction of aviation to Ford Island triggered expansion throughout Hawaii with the development of civilian airports, the creation of the Hawaii chapter of the [[National Aeronautic Association]], and a national flying code. The army's aviation division was generally favorably received by the Hawaiians, who took the military's investment in their land as a compliment.Lee 1966, p. 345. {| class = "wikitable" style="margin: auto;" ! colspan="3" |Army Air Force Aircraft at Luke Field{{cite web|url=http://hawaii.gov/hawaiiaviation/hawaii-airfields-airports/oahu-pre-world-war-ii/hickam-field-air-force-base/aircraft-stationed-at-hickam-afb-luke-field|title=Aircraft Stationed at Hickam AFB/Luke Field|publisher=State of Hawaii Department of Transportation, Airports Division|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} |- !Dates !Unit !Aircraft |- |1919–42 |[[5th Operations Group|2nd Group (Observation)]] later 5th Group (Observation) |{{mdash}} |- |1918–27 |[[6th Aero Squadron]] later 6th Pursuit Squadron |N-9, R-6, [[Curtiss HS|HS2L]], [[DH-4]], [[Curtiss JN-4|JN-6]], [[MB-3]], [[Fokker D.VII]] |- |1924–27 |[[19th Fighter Squadron|19th Pursuit Squadron]] |[[Curtiss JN-4|JN-6]], [[MB-3]], [[Royal Aircraft Factory S.E.5|S.E.5]], [[DH-4]] |- |1920–22, 1927–39 |[[4th Aero Squadron]] later 4th Observation Squadron |[[DH-4]], [[O-19]], [[OA-1]], [[Martin B-10|B-12]], [[Boeing P-12|P-12]] |- |1922–39 |[[23d Bomb Squadron (United States)|23d Squadron]] later 23d Bombardment Squadron |[[NBS-1]], [[Curtiss JN-4|JN-6]], [[DH-4]] |- |1923–39 |[[72d Test and Evaluation Squadron|72d Bombardment Squadron]] |[[DH-4]], [[NBS-1]], [[LB-5]] |- |1930–39 |[[50th Education Squadron|50th Observation Squadron]] later 50th Reconnaissance Squadron |[[O-19]] |} [[File:1919-1921 Luke Field.jpg|thumb|250px|alt=Aerial photo of shoreline buildings and docks|Ford Island, circa 1919–21]] The Navy decided that a Hawaiian base was a necessity, considering the Army field at Ford Island an ideal candidate.Burlingame 2013, p. 37. Naval Air Station Pearl Harbor, consisting of nine officers and fifty-five men, was commissioned on December 19, 1919. Although the Navy attempted to displace the Army from the island and designate it solely for naval use, [[United States Secretary of War|U.S. Secretary of War]] [[Newton D. Baker]] divided the island equally between the military branches.Burlingame 2013, p. 39.Dorrance 1998, p. 147. The Army received the west side of the island, and the Navy the southeastern side. Lieutenant Commander Robert D. Kirk-Patrick was sent to establish a naval station on the island with four airplanes and fifty-five men.{{cite web|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=76818|title=Kirkpatrick Field honors visionary commander who led Naval Weapons Station Yorktown through World War II|author=Mark O. Piggot|publisher=Naval Weapons Station Yorktown|date=September 26, 2013|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} Kirk-Patrick's men had two [[Curtiss HS|Curtiss HS2L]] flying boats and two N-9 planes salvaged from World War I, which they stored in two large canvas hangars across the harbor from the island. After the naval hangars were commissioned on January 17, 1923, by [[Lieutenant Commander]] [[John Rodgers (naval officer, World War I)|John Rodgers]], the detachment moved onto Ford Island and received [[Naval Aircraft Factory TS]], [[Felixstowe F5L]], [[Curtiss H-16]], [[Naval Aircraft Factory PN|Keystone PK-1]] and [[Douglas DT]] type aircraft.Burlingame 2013, p. 51. To accommodate ship berthing the Navy built a concrete-and-stone quay around the entire island, and in 1926, they received [[Vought FU]], [[Vought VE-7]] and [[Vought VE-9]] [[biplane]]s. [[File:Ford Island Pearl Harbor aerial 1930.jpg|thumb|250px|Aerial photo of Ford Island in 1930|alt=An island nearly three times long as it is wide with buildings scattered around the edges and grassy fields in the center]] During the 1930s, the Navy contracted a $1.5 million dredging of Pearl Harbor to allow larger battleships and the fleet's carriers to enter it. Work began in May 1940 resulting in {{convert|13000000|cuyd}} of material dredged from the opening of Pearl Harbor to build a channel to Ford Island as well as to create a [[canal|turning channel]] around the island.{{cite book|title=History of the Bureau of Yards and Docks and the Civil Engineer Corps 1940–1946|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/USN/Building_Bases/|publisher=United States Government Printing Office|accessdate=October 7, 2014|location = Washington|year = 1947}} Material was also dredged to deepen the West Loch, East Loch, and Middle Loch for the mooring of battleships. With dredged material used as land fill, the island's size was increased from {{convert|334|acre}} to {{convert|441|acre}}.Cohen 1981, p. 20. The Navy replaced its PK, F5L, and H16 aircraft with newer models (see table below). In 1933 [[VP-20|VP-8F]] arrived on station, and in 1935 the army bombers had become too large to be maintained and stored at Luke Field.Burlingame 2013, p. 93.Roberts 2000, p. 113. Construction began on a new Army airfield, [[Hickam Army Airfield]], named after pioneer [[United States Army Air Corps|U.S. Army Air Corps]] pilot [[Lieutenant Colonel]] [[Horace Meek Hickam]]. From 1936 to 1940 [[Pan American World Airways|Pan American]] flew its [[Pan Am Clipper#Clipper era|Clipper service]] into Ford Island, using it as a refueling stop between the United States and [[Asia]].{{cite web|url=http://hiavps.com/Luke%20Field.htm|title=Luke Field and NAS Pearl Harbor on Ford Island|date=August 9, 2012|publisher=Hawaii Aviation Preservation Society|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} The Navy built a $25,000 boathouse, spent $579,565 on a new crew barracks and built a firehouse, water-supply and lighting systems. In June 1936 the Navy lengthened the island's landing field by {{convert|400|ft}}, to {{convert|3000|ft}}. In March 1937 [[Amelia Earhart]], on her second visit to Luke Field, crashed her [[Lockheed Model 10 Electra|Lockheed Electra]] on takeoff.Burlingame 2013, p. 95. {| class = "wikitable" style="margin: auto;" ! colspan="3" |Naval aircraft at Naval Air Station Pearl Harbor in 1931 |- !Unit !Aircraft |- |[[VP-1|Patrol Squadron 1]] |6x [[Douglas T2D|T2D]] |- |[[VP-4|Patrol Squadron 4]] |12 [[Pomilio PE|PD-1]] |- |[[VP-6|Patrol Squadron 6]] |6x [[Martin T4M|T4M-1]]

1x [[Vought O2U Corsair|O2U]] |} In 1939, after three years of construction, Hickam Field opened. The Army transferred its operations there, leaving Luke Field under Navy control.Burlingame 2013, p. 97. The latter was renamed Naval Air Station Ford Island, and became the headquarters of [[Patrol Wing#Patrol and Reconnaissance Wing 2|Patrol Wing 2]]; its former namesake was re-honored with a new base, [[Luke Air Force Base]] in [[Arizona]].La Forte & Marcello 1991, pp. 91–100. A September 8, 1939, presidential emergency proclamation spurred the rapid construction of new facilities to prepare the island for additional operations. This included additional barracks, a new assembly and repair hangar, an administration building, a dispensary, a control tower, a laundry and a theater. At the height of World War II, over 40,000 people lived or worked on the island. ===Attack on Pearl Harbor=== {{main article|Attack on Pearl Harbor}} Beginning in the 1930s, [[Empire of Japan|Imperial Japan]] attempted to expand its territory into China. Opposed to these aggressive actions, the United States, [[United Kingdom|Britain]], and the [[Netherlands]] froze Japanese assets and imposed economic restrictions which prohibited the exportation of aircraft fuel as well as steel and iron to Japan, affecting 90% of Japan's war production needs.{{cite web|url=https://www.pearlharboroahu.com/attack.htm|title=Pearl Harbor, Oahu – The Attack: Facts and Information|publisher=Pearl Harbor Tours|accessdate=October 25, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Pearl Harbor History: Why Did Japan Attack? Eyewitness Accounts, Casualty List, Background|url=http://www.pearlharbor.org/history-of-pearl-harbor.asp|publisher=PearlHarbor.org|accessdate=October 25, 2014}} Japan was forced to either give up its expansion plans or find alternative raw materials to continue producing equipment for the war. Japan chose to continue with its plans, but decided it needed to neutralize any threat from the United States first. [[File:Damaged hangar on Ford Island in December 1941.jpeg|thumb|250px|Damaged hangar on Ford Island after the attacks|alt=Rafters and wooden structures of a bombed out hangar|alt=A large structure with most of the steel supports visible. Other materials that form the structure are burned, destroying, and hanging off the steel. A fire truck sits parked in front.]] Ford Island (in the center of Pearl Harbor) was the headquarters of Patrol Wing Two, an important target for the first-wave airborne raiders in the December 7, 1941, Japanese [[attack on Pearl Harbor]].{{Cite web|url = http://www.history.navy.mil/our-collections/photography/wars-and-events/world-war-ii/pearl-harbor-raid/overall-views-of-the-pearl-harbor-attack.html|title = Overall Views of the Pearl Harbor Attack|accessdate = 2015-06-12|publisher = Naval History and Heritage Command}}{{cite web|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/research/archives/digitized-collections/action-reports/wwii-pearl-harbor-attack/patrol-wing-pby-two-action-report.html |title=Patrol Wing TWO Report for Pearl Harbor Attack| accessdate=May 17, 2014 |location=Pearl Harbor, Territory of Hawaii|author=P.N.L. Bellinger|publisher = Naval History and Heritage Command}} Before dawn, the U.S. strategic center in the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] consisted of the seven battleships moored along [[Battleship Row]] and the six pairs of interrupted quays along the east side of Ford Island.{{Cite web|url = http://www.history.navy.mil/our-collections/photography/wars-and-events/world-war-ii/pearl-harbor-raid/battleship-row-during-the-pearl-harbor-attack.html|title = Battleship Row During the Attack|accessdate = 2015-06-12|publisher = Naval History and Heritage Command}} Quay F-2 (the southernmost), which usually [[Berth (moorings)|berthed]] an aircraft carrier, was empty. The [[United States Pacific Fleet|Pacific Fleet]] flagship {{USS|California|BB-44|2}} was moored northeastward, at F-3. Side by side with the {{USS|Maryland|BB-46|2}} was {{USS|Oklahoma|BB-37|2}} (outboard), followed by {{USS|Tennessee|BB-43|2}} with {{USS|West Virginia|BB-48|2}} outboard. Behind ''Tennessee'' was [[USS Arizona (BB-39)|''Arizona'']] alongside the repair ship ''Vestal''. Closing the row was {{USS|Nevada|BB-36|2}}, alone at F-8. These battleships, from eighteen to twenty-five years old, represented all but two of those available to the Pacific Fleet. {{USS|Pennsylvania|BB-38|2}} was also in Pearl Harbor, being dry-docked at the Navy Yard. The ninth battleship of the fleet, {{USS|Colorado|BB-45|2}}, was being overhauled on the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]]. These nine battleships taken together were one short of equaling Japan's active battle fleet, although most of the Japanese vessels were newer. {| style="float: left; margin: 10px;" class="wikitable" |+ Pearl Harbor during the attack |[[File:Pearlmap2.png|250px|alt=Map of Pearl Harbor, with locations of battleships and facilities]] | valign=top rowspan="2" | 1:[[w:USS California (BB-44)|''California'']]

D:Naval yard |- |[[File:Phdepth.png|250px|Depth key for Pearl Harbor map]] |} The initial bombs struck the island at 07:57 local time, prompting the historic dispatch: "Air Raid, Pearl Harbor—this is no drill."Day 1960, p. 271. The battleships ringing Ford Island were the Japanese attackers' primary targets. Twenty-four of the forty Japanese torpedo planes were assigned to attack Battleship Row, and five more came over to that side of Ford Island after failing to find battleships in other parts of the harbor. The planes carried 29 [[Type 91 torpedo#Thunder fish|Type 91 aerial torpedoes]], each with a high-explosive payload of {{convert|450|lb}}, of which 12 are thought to have found their targets: two in ''California'', one in ''Nevada'' and a possible total of nine in ''Oklahoma'' and ''West Virginia''; the latter two ships sank within minutes of being hit. Horizontal bomber aircraft delivering armor-piercing bombs attacked as the last torpedo planes finished, and other horizontal and [[dive bomber]]s came in later. The aircraft registered many direct hits and damaging near-misses, including two each on ''California'', ''Maryland'' and ''Tennessee'' and several more on ''West Virginia''. [[File:PLanes burning-Ford Island-Pearl Harbor.jpg|thumb|250px|Hangar 6 in flames after the attack on Ford Island|alt=A burning hangar with destroyed planes scattered in front]] A bomb meant for the ''California'' hit Hangar 6 on the island, igniting it. Additional bombs hit Hangar 38 (a dud), the dispensary courtyard (leaving a large crater) and the road outside the repair-and-assembly hangar. Only one man, Theodore Wheeler Croft, was killed on the island while standing guard duty. The bombers' most notable success was ''Arizona''. A bomb exploded near the forward magazines, triggering a catastrophic explosion which immediately sank the ship. The island's freshwater supply was cut off when the ''Arizona'' severed the main water line and the auxiliary line was destroyed at the Pearl Harbor end. The ''Nevada'', which eventually got underway while under attack, was hit repeatedly by dive bombers who spotted a ship escaping from Ford Island. So she would not sink between the island and the Navy Yard (blocking the entire harbor), ''Nevada'' was run aground. Several planes from the aircraft carrier {{USS|Enterprise|CV-6|2}}, near Hawaii after a mission to [[Wake Island]], arrived in the midst of the attack; four were shot down by American air-defense friendly fire.{{cite web|url = http://www.history.navy.mil/our-collections/photography/wars-and-events/world-war-ii/pearl-harbor-raid/attacks-on-airfields-and-aerial-combat/naval-air-station--ford-island--during-the-pearl-harbor-raid.html|title = Naval Air Station, Ford Island|accessdate = 2015-06-12|publisher = Naval History and Heritage Command}} H. L. Young, commander of ''Enterprise'' air group, attempted to man the control tower to provide communications between the island, ''Enterprise'', and the planes. However, he reported that although he attempted to communicate with ''Enterprise'' by radio from Ford Island, the communications systems there were inadequate,{{cite book|title=History of United States Naval Operations in World War II: The rising sun in the Pacific, 1931 – April 1942|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=piEUmkf8o_cC|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=2001|isbn=978-0-252-06973-4|author=Samuel Eliot Morison|location=Illinois}}{{cite web|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/docs/wwii/pearl/ph17.htm|title=Report of Action with Japanese Air Force at Oahu, T.H., December 7, 1941.|author=Commander H. L. Young|date=December 15, 1941|publisher=National Archives and Records Administration|accessdate=June 25, 2014}} and he attributed the friendly fire to ineffective radio communications. After attempting to notify as many ships and anti-aircraft batteries as possible, several planes from ''Enterprise'' and others from Ford Island's complement were again airborne within hours to search for the attackers. Some of these search planes were again shot down on their return by friendly fire from the Ford Island defense, which was on high alert. In addition to Battleship Row and the island's naval field, the fixed moorings on the western side of Ford Island (capable of securing battleships or aircraft carriers) were high-priority targets.{{cite web|url = http://www.history.navy.mil/our-collections/photography/wars-and-events/world-war-ii/pearl-harbor-raid/attacks-off-the-west-side-of-ford-island.html|title = Attacks off the West Side of Ford Island|accessdate = 2015-06-12|publisher = Naval History and Heritage Command}} Just west of the island, the [[seaplane tender]] [[USS Curtiss (AV-4)|''Curtiss'']] was hit by a crashing dive bomber, a bomb and fragments of another bomb. She was then unsuccessfully attacked by a Japanese [[Type A Kō-hyōteki-class submarine|midget submarine]], which fired a torpedo before being sunk by the destroyer [[USS Monaghan (DD-354)|''Monaghan'']]. Hangar 6 and several patrol seaplanes and other aircraft on Ford Island (33 out of 70 of the island's planes) were destroyed.{{cite web|url=http://hawaii.gov/hawaiiaviation/world-war-ii/december-7-1941|title=The Attack on Pearl Harbor|publisher=State of Hawaii|accessdate=May 25, 2014}} ====Aftermath==== [[File:Righting of the USS Oklahoma with winches on Ford Island.jpg|thumb|250px|The ''Oklahoma'', righted to about 30 degrees on March 29, 1943, during salvage at Pearl Harbor|alt=A ship on its side halfway underwater with cables strung to winches on the island behind it.]] The Japanese disabled all seven battleships on Battleship Row. ''Maryland'', ''Tennessee'' and ''Pennsylvania'' were repaired in only a few weeks and three others within a year,{{cite web|url = http://www.history.navy.mil/our-collections/photography/wars-and-events/world-war-ii/pearl-harbor-raid/post-attack-ship-salvage.html|title = Post-Attack Ship Salvage|accessdate = 2015-06-14|publisher = Naval History and Heritage Command}} but ''Oklahoma'' and ''Arizona'' were total losses. The weakened state of the US Pacific Fleet would allow the Japanese Navy to hold the initiative until the [[Guadalcanal Campaign]] eight months later.{{Cite web|url = http://www.history.navy.mil/our-collections/photography/wars-and-events/world-war-ii/pearl-harbor-raid/raid-aftermath.html|title = Raid Aftermath|accessdate = 2015-06-14|publisher = Naval History and Heritage Command}} ''Enterprise'' launched aircraft to patrol Ford Island and search for Japanese carriers.Allen 1999, p. 27. Five American pilots returning from missions to hunt down the Japanese fleet were mistakenly shot down by Ford Island anti-aircraft gunners while attempting to land. The island's commanding officer said about the friendly-fire losses, "Somebody let fly and I never saw so many bullets in the air in my life and never expect to ... all tracer bullets at night." After the attack, [[ROTC]] cadets from the [[University of Hawaii]] were assigned to active duty guarding strategic buildings.Cohen 1981, p. 153. Because of the island's lack of fresh water and electric power to the dispensary, a temporary hospital had to be set up at the #2 barracks. The island's gasoline tank was emptied and refilled with water; trenches were dug, and buildings camouflaged. Its runway was cleared of over three tons of scrap metal in two hours.Prange, Goldstein, & Dillon 1988, pp. 332–333. The Marines who had picked up rifles for guard duty were tasked with feeding and clothing the soldiers and sailors. Twenty prisoners from the island's brig were marched to the Marine barracks and put to work without incident; some received commuted sentences for their efforts. That evening, Hawaiians were instructed to observe an indoor [[Blackout (wartime)|blackout]], stay off the telephone, keep extra buckets of water available for fighting fires and keep cars off the streets (parking them on lawns, if necessary). Sixty concrete [[Revetment (aircraft)|revetments]] were constructed to protect aircraft from another attack, and the Navy laid down a {{convert|16|inch|adj=on}} water main from across the harbor. A new control tower was commissioned on May 1, 1942, and the Navy built bomb shelters and gas-decontamination chambers. Due to the need for better control of the US Pacific Fleet, its headquarters moved to Ford Island. During the next few weeks, the Navy set up twenty-one large winches on the island to turn the ''Oklahoma'' upright so it could be re-floated and patched before being scrapped.{{cite web|url = http://www.history.navy.mil/our-collections/photography/wars-and-events/world-war-ii/pearl-harbor-raid/post-attack-ship-salvage/salvage-of-uss-oklahoma--1942-1944.html|title = Salvage of USS Oklahoma, 1942-1944|publisher = Naval History & Heritage Command|accessdate = 2015-06-14}} Coral was piled between the ship and the island so the ship would roll upright, instead of sliding toward the shore. ''Oklahoma'' sank during a mid-Pacific storm while it was being towed to the scrapyard. ''Nevada'', ''California'', ''West Virginia'' and the [[minelayer]] [[USS Oglala (CM-4)|USS ''Oglala'']] were re-floated and salvaged by the Navy. The entire salvage operation took 20,000 man-hours underwater and 5,000 dives to recover human remains, weapons, ammunition and artifacts of historic or military importance. ==Naval Auxiliary Landing Field Ford Island== [[File:Waa Hele Honoa (YFB-83) and Moko Holo Hele (YFB-87).png|thumb|250px|''Moko Holo Hele'' (''left'') and ''Waa Hele Honoa'', ferries serving Ford Island|alt=Two large ferries docked on an island on a clear day]] The US Pacific Fleet established the Fleet Intelligence Center, Pacific (FICPAC) on Ford Island by 1955 as the [[Vietnam War]] escalated and an additional intelligence branch was needed in addition to the one in [[Guam]].{{cite book|title=Historical Dictionary of Naval Intelligence|publisher=Scarecrow Press|date=April 28, 2010|isbn=978-0-8108-7377-3|page=111|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OyC69ij3AQIC|location=Washington D.C.}}Hastedt 2010, p. 300. With little other use of the island, as naval and air operations were moved to facilities on the side of the Pearl Harbor previously owned by the Bishop estate, the Navy decommissioned Naval Air Station Ford Island in 1966.{{cite journal|magazine=Naval Aviation News|date=October 1965|title=Quiet arrives after 40 years|author=Lieutenant Commander James E. Wise Jr.|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/content/dam/nhhc/research/histories/naval-aviation/Naval%20Aviation%20News/1960/pdf/oct65.pdf | format=PDF |accessdate=May 16, 2014}} The island continued to be controlled by the Navy as a sub-component of Naval Air Station Pearl Harbor. On February 20, 1970, the 4,000-foot (1,200 m) runway at NALF Ford Island was opened to civilian flight training operations, primarily local Army, Navy, Air Force and Marine Corps flying clubs. Itinerant military helicopter training activities also continued at NALF Ford Island during this period. Hawaii (which achieved statehood in 1959) contracted with the US Navy to allow [[touch-and-go landing]]s until 1972, when the airfield was opened to students making their first solo flights. The island's use as a training center helped relieve congestion at nearby [[Honolulu International Airport]].{{cite news| last=Kakesako| first=Gregg K.| title=Farewell to Ford Isle ferries| date=April 13, 1998| newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin| url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/98/04/13/news/story2.html| accessdate=April 19, 2009}} After its active-duty commission on February 1, 1973 the [[United States Third Fleet|Third Fleet]] moved its headquarters to Ford Island, where it remained until its 1991 move to San Diego.{{cite web|url=http://www.c3f.navy.mil/history.html|title=Third Fleet History|date=January 15, 2014|publisher=United States Third Fleet|accessdate=May 28, 2014}} The island remained home to Navy officers and several naval headquarters.Dorrance 1998, p. 149. {| class="wikitable" ! The new airport was open to general aviation and rendered NALF Ford Island redundant. Before the completion of the [[Admiral Clarey Bridge]], access to Ford Island was by [[List of auxiliaries of the United States Navy#Yard Ferry Boats or Launches (YFB)|ferry]]. Two diesel-powered ferries, ''Waa Hele Honoa'' (YFB-83) and ''Moko Holo Hele'' (YFB-87), served the island. The ''Waa Hele Honoa'' (meaning "canoe go to land") was purchased in 1959 for $274,000, and pressed into service by the Navy on March 3, 1961. It is the older and larger of the two ferries, at {{convert|181|ft}}, with a capacity of 750 people and 33 vehicles. The other, ''Moko Holo Hele'' (meaning "boat go back and forth") was purchased for $1.1 million on May 25, 1970. At {{convert|162|ft}}, its capacity was 750 people and 42 vehicles. Both ferries were operated by US Navy personnel, and access to the island was restricted to US military personnel, their dependents and invited guests. In addition to the two car ferries, there were several smaller "foot ferries" allowing pedestrians to travel between Ford Island and alternate landings around Pearl Harbor. ===Rebirth=== [[File:Military and civilian runners crossing the Admiral Clarey Bridge during the 2006 Ford Island 10k Bridge Run at Pearl Harbor.jpg|thumb|right|More than 1,400 military and civilian runners make their way across the Adm. Bernard "Chick" Clarey Bridge during the 2006 Ford Island 10k Bridge Run at Pearl Harbor.|alt=Hundreds of runners at the start line of a marathon at the O'ahu side of the Admiral Clarey bridge.]] Initially called "the bridge to nowhere", the Admiral Clarey Bridge was instrumental in Senator [[Daniel Inouye]]'s "rebirth" of Ford Island and enabled over $500 million in development with special legislation (2814 US Code).{{UnitedStatesCode|10|2814}}{{cite news|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20030807005845/en/Hunt-Fluor-Partnership-Awarded-Contract-U.S.-Navys-Ford#.UwSNpE3iuJA|title=Hunt-Fluor Partnership Awarded Contract For US Navy's Ford Island Project|author=Business Editors/Photo Editors|date=August 7, 2003|accessdate=February 13, 2014|agency=BusinessWire}}{{cite news|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2007/09/02/news/story05.html|title=A Reborn Ford Island Hosts Military Minds|first=Gregg K. |last= Kakesako|date=September 2, 2007|work=Star-Bulletin|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} It connected 45 families and 3,000 civilian workers to [[Kamehameha Highway]], and visitor access enabled construction of the $50 million {{convert|16|acre|adj=on}} [[Pacific Aviation Museum Pearl Harbor|Pacific Aviation Museum]].{{cite news|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2004/Dec/07/ln/ln10p.html|title=Ford Island Builds on Its History|first=Will|last= Hoover|newspaper=Honolulu Advertiser|date=December 7, 2004|accessdate=February 13, 2014}} Plans included 500 homes for Navy personnel, a child-development center and a Navy lodge.{{cite news|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/98/04/14/news/story6.html|title=Bridge Opens Path to Ford Island Development|first=Gregg K. |last=Kakesako|work=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|date=April 14, 1998|accessdate=February 13, 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2002/12/01/news/index8.html|title=Ford Island fund-raiser set|author=Gregg K. Kakesako|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|date=December 1, 2002|accessdate=May 12, 2014}} In planning the island's development, the Navy considered its operational needs and the island's historic value.{{cite web|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2001/Jun/25/ln/ln01a.html|title=Ford Island caught in tug-of-war between Navy, preservationists|date=June 25, 2001|newspaper=Honolulu Advertiser|author=William Cole|accessdate=June 5, 2014}} However, the National Trust for Historic Preservation considered the Navy's communication style more directive rather than collaborative, restricting the NTHP's ability to share their concerns, and in 2001 designated Ford Island one of its 11 most-endangered sites. Although the Navy's plans included preserving important hangars, the control tower and seaplane ramps, they failed to protect the existing runway and 1920s housing and did not address preserving bullet holes on the seaplane ramps. As hoped by the Trust, after the designation the Navy agreed to delay development of some of these items until an agreement could be reached. To accommodate additional facilities and housing, the Navy needed to upgrade the island's [[infrastructure]].{{cite web|url=http://trenchlessonline.com/index/webapp-stories-action/id.200|title=5,000-ft HDD bore of electrical conduit completed as part of infrastructure upgrade at famous site|author=Grady Bell|publisher=Trenchless Technology|date=June 1, 2006|accessdate=May 25, 2014}} Its sewage system was upgraded with the 2001 installation of a {{convert|6000|ft|adj=on}}, {{convert|20|in|adj=on}} sewage main from the island to Pearl Harbor and improvements to the sewage-pumping station.{{cite web|url=http://fukunagaengineers.com/projects/award-winning-projects/fy01-mcon-project-p-491/|title=FY01 MCON Project P-491, Sewer Force Main – Ford Island to Pearl Harbor Naval Shipyard|date=May 15, 2001|accessdate=May 25, 2014|publisher = Fukunaga & Associates, Inc.}} Due to the bridge's unique design, which includes a floating section, it was impossible to use it to transit cable across the loch. In 2005, the Navy contracted drilling for primary and auxiliary conduits {{convert|20|ft}} apart and parallel to the bridge from Halawa Landing to the Ford Island golf course. The contractor installed {{convert|5045|ft|adj=on}}-long, {{convert|24|in|adj=on}}-thick carbon-steel high-magnetic casing conduits, and fiber-optic communications cables and 46kV power lines were fed through them. [[File:Ford Island photovoltaic panels concept.png|thumb|250px|[[Conceptual design]] for photovoltaic panels covering the Ford Island runway|alt=An island with building on the left and right. Center is a conceptual design of the runway covered in solar panels.]] In June 2013 the Navy planned to install 60,000 [[Photovoltaics|photovoltaic panels]] over {{convert|28|acre}} on the Ford Island runway,{{cite news|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/s?action=login&f=y&id=211343851&id=211343851|title=Navy halts move for solar project on historic runway|date=June 13, 2013|newspaper=Star Advertiser|author=William Cole|accessdate=March 12, 2014}} to comply with Congressional and Defense Department mandates to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and offset the cost of Hawaiian energy (the highest in the United States). This plan deviated from a 2009 proposal (using the panels to define the runway) in favor of panels producing twice the power.{{cite news|title=Buffeted by opposition, Navy blinks on solar site|publisher=McClatchy-Tribute Regional News|author=William Cole|date=October 1, 2012}} The Navy offered the Pacific Aviation Museum Pearl Harbor $250,000 toward renovation of the control tower's elevator in exchange for its support of the plan. The museum declined, organizing an internet campaign opposing the plan based on the runway's historic significance and highlighting Ford Island's role in the attack on Pearl Harbor and Amelia Earhart's visit. In response, the Navy decided to install the panels on existing structures around Pearl Harbor. ==={{anchor|Present-day use}}Present use=== Ford Island continues to be used by the US Navy. It hosts the {{convert|34000|sqft|adj=on}} [[Pacific Warfighting Center]] for exercises, training and battle simulations.{{cite web|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2007/09/02/news/story05.html|title=A reborn Ford Island hosts military minds|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|date=September 2, 2007|issue=245|volume=12|accessdate=November 3, 2014}} The Admiral Clarey Bridge enabled the Navy to develop a $331 million Pacific tsunami warning center named after Senator Daniel Inouye, replacing the aging facility on {{okina}}Ewa Beach.{{cite report |url=http://images.huntelp.com/html/files/ford_island_case_study.pdf | format=PDF |title=Ford Island Case Study WEB11.6.12-01|first=David P. |last= Kunzelman|publisher=Hunt Companies|date=November 6, 2012|accessdate=February 11, 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/s?action=login&f=y&id=210738681&id=210738681|title=Group Questions Safety of New Tsunami Center|first=Gary T. |last=Kubota|work=Honolulu Star-Advertiser|date=June 9, 2013|accessdate=February 13, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/25347332/pacific-tsunami-warning-centers-defends-controversial-move|title=Pacific Tsunami Warning Center defends controversial move|author=Lisa Kubota|date=April 25, 2014|publisher=Hawaii News Now|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} The center's location is controversial because of its location in a tsunami-vulnerable area and the Navy's tsunami-evacuation plan calls for the island's only access point—the Admiral Clarey Bridge—to be opened for ship evacuation (making the bridge inaccessible to land vehicles).{{cite web|url=http://www.civilbeat.com/articles/2013/06/11/19255-could-hawaiis-new-tsunami-warning-center-survive-a-giant-wave/|title=Could Hawaii's New Tsunami Warning Center Survive a Giant Wave?|author=Sara Lin|date=June 11, 2013|work=Honolulu Civil Beat|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} The island also continues to host a military brig.{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/2001-12-06/news/25307497_1_ford-island-pearl-harbor-everett-hyland|date=December 6, 2001|author=Tim Infield|work=The Inquirer|title=Attack from the blue resonates anew Pearl Harbor looms larger since Sept. 11.|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} Nominally based in Alaska, the [[Sea-based X-band Radar]] (SBX-1) arrived on Ford Island in 2006 for maintenance and repairs and has returned several times since.{{cite web|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/news/20110123_On_the_ball.html?id=114443724 |title=Pearl Harbor has become the X-Band radar's informal home |date=January 23, 2011 |author=William Cole |work=Honolulu Star-Advertiser |accessdate=May 18, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140519030106/http://www.staradvertiser.com/news/20110123_On_the_ball.html?id=114443724 |archivedate=May 19, 2014 }} Primarily used as a warhead-detection radar system on a self-propelled floating platform in the Pacific, its presence on the island has been controversial.{{cite web|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2006/Sep/03/ln/FP609030345.html|title=Radar staying longer than planned|date=September 3, 2006|work=Honolulu Advertiser|author=Kristen Scharnberg|accessdate=May 28, 2014}} The platform, with a cost reaching nearly {{currency|1000000000}}, has never actually made it to Alaska and conspiracy theorists argue that the platform is a mobile version of the [[High Frequency Active Auroral Research Program]].{{cite web|url=http://www.exohuman.com/wordpress/2011/05/floating-haarp-platform-spotted-in-seattle/|title=Floating HAARP Platform Spotted in Seattle|publisher=ExoHuman|accessdate=September 4, 2014}} In 2013, the Navy unveiled a $4-million training facility, using simulators and virtual reality, at the Naval Undersea Warfare Center Division Keyport on Ford Island.{{cite web|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=78018|title=Mission Possible: Simulation-based Training and Experimentation on Display|author=Eric Beidel|publisher=Office of Naval Research|date=December 2, 2013|accessdate=May 22, 2014}} The Fleet Integrated Synthetic Training/Testing Facility (FIST2FAC) was developed to save on training costs with a reusable facility which could emulate electronic, mine and anti-air warfare scenarios instead of real-world training requiring fuel, logistics and deployment costs for ships.{{cite web|url=http://navylive.dodlive.mil/2013/12/06/navy-training-merges-virtual-and-real-worlds/|title=Navy Training Merges Virtual and Real Worlds|author=Glenn White|publisher=Office of Naval Research|date=December 6, 2013|accessdate=May 22, 2014}} ==Memorials and museums== [[File:Pearl Harbor Historic Sites.jpg|thumb|250px|Sign in front of the Pearl Harbor Historic Sites at Halawa Landing on O{{okina}}ahu|alt=Blue plaque with the names of museums and memorials at the Pearl Harbor historic sites]] {{main article|USS Arizona Memorial|USS Utah (BB-31)#Memorial|USS Missouri (BB-63)#Museum ship (1998 to present)|USS Oklahoma (BB-37)#Memorial|Pacific Aviation Museum Pearl Harbor|l1=USS ''Arizona'' memorial|l2=USS ''Utah'' memorial|l3=USS ''Missouri'' museum|l4=USS ''Oklahoma'' memorial}} Soon after the attack on Pearl Harbor, it was decided that the USS ''Arizona'' would remain at the bottom of the harbor as the final resting place for those lost.{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/TwHP/wwwlps/lessons/18arizona/18facts2.htm|title=Reading 2: The USS Arizona Memorial|publisher=National Park Service|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315120007/http://www.nps.gov/history/nr/TwHP/wwwlps/lessons/18arizona/18facts2.htm|archivedate=March 15, 2008|accessdate=May 17, 2014|date=August 15, 2007}} In 1958, President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] approved the construction of a memorial over the vessel and the USS ''Arizona'' memorial was dedicated in 1962.Doughty 2010, p. 116. It includes a complex at Halawa Landing (opposite Ford Island) and a structure over the ''Arizona'' which receives visitors by ferry.Dorrance 1998, p. 169. Although the ferries are operated by US Navy personnel, the complex is staffed by the National Park Service. In January 29, 1964, the navy facility in Pearl Harbor centering on the Ford Island was designated "United States Naval Base, Pearl Harbor" and became a [[National Historic Landmark]].{{Cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=713&ResourceType=District|title=United States Naval Base, Pearl Harbor|publisher= National Park Service| access-date=June 17, 2015}} The battleship USS ''Utah'', which was actually a test dummy, remains submerged off the island.Dorrance 1998, p. 148. After salvaging the capsized USS ''Oklahoma'' with winching cables, the Navy unsuccessfully tried to recover the ''Utah'' using the same technique.{{cite web|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/our-collections/photography/wars-and-events/world-war-ii/pearl-harbor-raid/post-attack-ship-salvage/righting-of-uss-utah--1943-1944.html|title=Righting of USS Utah, 1943–1944|publisher=Naval History & Heritage Command|date=October 10, 2011|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} In 1972, the remains of the ''Utah'' (on the northwest side of the island) were dedicated as a memorial to the fifty-eight men still inside.Cohen 1981. p 150. Despite concern that it would detract from the ''Arizona'' memorial, in 1998 the USS ''Missouri'' was transferred from Washington State to Ford Island.{{cite news|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/98/06/15/news/story1.html|title=Pride & Glory|work=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|author=Gregg K. Kakesako|date=June 15, 1998|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} After a year of conversion into a museum, the ship opened for visitors on January 29, 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.trumanlibrary.org/trivia/ussmo.htm|title=FAQ: Where is the USS Missouri now? Can you visit it and go aboard?|publisher=Harry S. Truman Library & Museum}}{{cite news|url=http://www.hookelenews.com/battleship-missouri-memorial-celebrates-anniversaries/|author=Ho'okele Staff|date=January 31, 2014|publisher=Ho'okele Pearl Harbor-Hickam News|title=Battleship Missouri Memorial celebrates anniversaries|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} On December 7, 2006, the 65th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor, the aviation museum opened to visitors in Hangar 37 after more than ten years of planning.{{cite journal|title=Pearl Harbor Museum|publisher=Plane and Pilot|year=2005|via=HighBeam Research|accessdate=March 2, 2014|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1032043701.html|subscription=yes}} On December 7, 2007, a joint ceremony was held by the National Park Service and the USS ''Oklahoma'' memorial committee to dedicate a memorial to the ship just outside the entrance to the USS ''Missouri'' museum on the northeast side of the island.{{cite web|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=33875|title=USS Oklahoma Memorial Dedicated on Ford Island|date=December 13, 2007|publisher=Navy Region Hawaii Public Affairs|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} The Pacific Aviation Museum Pearl Harbor signed a lease with the US Navy on September 2, 2010, for the Ford Island control tower, which sent the first radio alert of the attack, and began its restoration.{{cite web|url=http://www.navy.mil/submit/display.asp?story_id=55827|title=Pacific Aviation Museum Prepares Ford Island Air Tower for Renovation|date=September 8, 2010|author=PO2 Robert Stirrup|publisher=Navy Region Hawaii Public Affairs|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} ==Film and television== A 1965 film, ''[[In Harm's Way]]'' starring [[John Wayne]], was filmed on Ford Island. A fictionalized scene before the attack, with officers and their wives at a pool party, was reenacted by island residents on the anniversary of the attacks as late as 2001. In 1970, the island's control tower was repainted for the filming of ''Tora! Tora! Tora!''.{{cite web|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/Dec/17/ln/hawaii712170348.html|title=Museum will give Hawaii tower facelift|author=William Cole|work=Honolulu Advertiser|date=December 17, 2007|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} A [[Boeing B-17 Flying Fortress]] used in the production experienced a landing-gear malfunction and crash-landed on Ford Island, and the crash landing was included in the film.{{cite web|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2000/04/17/news/story1.html|title=Mock-Japanese warplane crashed on Ford Island|author=Gregg K. Kakesako|work=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|date=April 17, 2000|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} [[File:US Navy 040722-N-9662L-031 USS John C. Stennis (CVN 74) passes the USS Arizona and her memorial plaque as it arrives in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.jpg|thumb|250px|Memorial plaque on Ford Island, facing the USS ''Arizona'' memorial|alt=A golden plaque on stone on the shore of Ford Island, with a white memorial bridge floating over the USS Arizona|alt=The USS Arizona memorial standing over the remains of the destroyed battleship. The memorial is white and sits atop the water with a flag in the middle.]] In April 2000, filming began on the [[Michael Bay]] film ''Pearl Harbor''.{{cite web|url=http://gohawaii.about.com/cs/hawaiifilms/a/pearl_movie.htm|title=Pearl Harbor – The Making of the Film|author=John Fischer|publisher=About.com|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} Before the filming, the cast and crew gathered on the USS ''Arizona'' memorial for a wreath-laying by a representative of [[Touchstone Pictures]], [[Jerry Bruckheimer]] and Bay. The producers brought fifteen vintage planes to Ford Island, placing them in one hangar for the filming.{{cite news|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2000/04/03/news/story2.html|title=It will be Dec. 7, 1941, all over again|author=Tim Ryan|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|date=April 3, 2000|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} In addition, they brought fifteen ships back to Pearl Harbor for live bombardment (without sinking them). The operations room of the control tower was converted into a barracks for the filming. The Pacific Aviation Museum hoped that the film would increase public awareness of the tower and spur support for its restoration.{{cite web|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/2001/05/20/news/story9.html|title=Air museum hopes to fly on movie's wings|author=Gregg K. Kakesako|date=May 20, 2001|work=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} Bay reflected on the historic significance of Ford Island: "I have a vivid memory of showing the crew around Ford Island during pre-production. We came upon a plaque directly across from the sunken Arizona, marking the spot where a torpedo hit nearly six decades ago. My crew stood in silence for three minutes at the sight of this small monument. It was a solemn moment for all of us, and I think it helped the crew appreciate the undertaking were {{sic}} about to begin."{{cite web|url=http://michaelbay.com/project/pearl-harbor/|title=Pearl Harbor|author=Michael Bay|accessdate=May 17, 2014}} During filming, a [[Vultee BT-13 Valiant]] used as a [[torpedo bomber]] crashed on the island. In 2010, the television series ''[[Hawaii Five-0]]'' chose Battleship Cove, a housing community just outside the dock of the USS ''Missouri'' museum, as the location for an episode.{{cite web|url=http://www.hookelenews.com/forest-city-residents-experience-%E2%80%98star-action%E2%80%99-in-their-backyards/|title=Forest City residents experience 'star action' in their backyards|author=Natasha Jackson|date=September 25, 2010|publisher=Ho'okele "Navigator"|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} The episode, with police cars racing down Tennessee and Nevada Streets, featured a number of Ford Island homes and some residents appeared as extras. That year, [[Peter Berg]] featured the USS ''Missouri'' in the film ''[[Battleship (film)|Battleship]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/features/20111113__Whatever_the_plot_Missouri_has_big_role_in_Battleship.html|title=Whatever the plot, Missouri has big role in 'Battleship'|author=Mike Gordon|work=Honolulu Star-Advertiser|date=November 13, 2011|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} The ship, which was towed off Ford Island for maintenance, was brought out to sea between completion of the maintenance and its return to the dock for filming.
